Quantum theory is often described as a theory of states on algebras of observables. However, this description is not mathematically precise. In this paper, we provide a precise mathematical description of quantum theory in terms of continuous linear functionals on appropriate spaces of states. This description is based on a categorical construction that we call the “algebraic description of quantum theory.” The algebraic description of quantum theory is a category whose objects are algebras of observables and whose morphisms are states. The category is equivalent to the category of continuous linear functionals on the appropriate spaces of states. This equivalence is a mathematical reformulation of the operational meaning of quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasitic animals that are of great interest because of their extreme reduction in body plan and gene content. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals and that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to a simple structure, the polar capsule. We also show that myxozoans are a sister group to the cnidarians and that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results provide insights into the evolution of the Myxozoa and the extreme reduction in gene content that is characteristic of parasitic animals. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses. This will have important consequences for food security, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. Our results show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 7% under 2 °C warming and to 86% under 4 °C warming. This will have important consequences for food security, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. We also show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will be zero under 2 °C warming for all four major maize-exporting countries, but it will be 70% for China and 90% for the United States. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is important for understanding the mechanisms of coexistence in large herbivore communities. However, the extent to which species differ in their food-resource use is largely unknown because of the difficulty of species-level identification of food resources. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify the food resources consumed by seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that the degree of overlap in food-resource use was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, species differed in their food-resource use, and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore communities. Our results also suggest that L megaherbivore diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the management of large herbivore communities.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of COVID-19 on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. Finally, many businesses plan to seek funding through the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris by food webs and ballasting processes. This study highlights the importance of size-selective sinks in the ocean and the need for a better understanding of the fate of plastic debris in the ocean.

The origin of the elements is one of the most important questions in astrophysics. The study of presolar grains, which are nucleosynthetically unique, provides a unique window into the early history of our solar system. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also determined that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results provide evidence for an early episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The results also provide evidence that the bulk of the solar system’s elements were formed in the interstellar medium. This is in contrast to the current paradigm that the bulk of the elements were formed in the interior of the sun. The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could double again by midcentury, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of all species. In placental mammals, the ability to reproduce is limited by the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy is limited by the mother’s own metabolic power and the amount of energy available to her from the environment. Here, we show that the ability to access more energy from the environment correlates with an increase in reproductive output. This suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output in placental mammals is the mother’s own metabolic power. This is important because it suggests that the evolution of reproductive output is largely determined by the mother’s physiology and not by the environment. This is a fundamental insight into the evolution of placental mammals. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls vascular contractility, hemostasis, and inflammation and regulates the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between circulating blood and tissue. To control each function, the endothelium processes endlessly arriving requests from multiple sources using separate clusters of cells specialized to detect specific stimuli. A well-developed but poorly understood communication system operates between cells to integrate multiple lines of information and coordinate endothelial responses. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. This study provides a foundation for understanding the function of the endothelium and its role in health and disease. The findings also provide a basis for developing new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a rich set of data on COVID activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not available elsewhere. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are relevant for tracking the pandemic, for augmenting traditional public health reporting, and for empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are a large family of ion channels that are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes. They are also involved in a number of diseases, such as epilepsy, cardiac arrhythmia, and diabetes. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also shown that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. It also provides a structural basis for closed-state inactivation in this ion-channel family. This work is expected to provide a structural basis for the design of new drugs that target potassium channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health. The role of the anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We identified 146 genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for diverse types of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobial peptides, and polyketide-related compounds. These results support the finding that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products, which could be harnessed as a source of antimicrobials, therapeutics, and other bioactive compounds. This work provides a resource for the discovery of novel natural products from anaerobic fungi. The results also highlight the potential of anaerobic fungi to be used as a source of natural products in the future.

Social dominance is a key feature of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design composite structures with multiple material phases to achieve arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized and effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

We also show that IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is essential for fetal hemoglobin expression. Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) function, highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells. This resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by producing monounsaturated fatty acids. Genetic or pharmacologic ablation of SREBP1 or SCD1 sensitized ferroptosis in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The underlying mechanisms of hypertension are complex and include the vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) phenotype. VSMCs are the main cells in the blood vessel wall and play a critical role in the development of hypertension. We show that the three major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in VSMCs. LCCBs act on the STIM N terminus to cause STIM relocalization to junctions and subsequent ORAI activation in a Cav1.2-independent and store depletion-independent manner. LCCB-induced promotion of VSMC remodeling requires STIM1, which is up-regulated in VSMCs from hypertensive rats. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP had the intended effect on biodiversity. We found that bird populations tracked changes in forest composition, but the policy failed to halt declines of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP has been criticized for not halting declines of older forests. Our results suggest that the policy was successful in halting clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP has been extended, and we need to continue to monitor the effects of the policy on biodiversity. Our results also underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibacterial agents is essential to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. The approach is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We show that the best candidate designed by us is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and is more active than the best compound identified by a previous experimental approach. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The approach presented here can be used to identify new antibiotics for other pathogens. This will help to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens and to fight the global threat of antibiotic resistance. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations. The resulting architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. This makes it easier to train and apply in practice. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of these devices on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin, phase-shifts the circadian clock, and reduces alertness the following morning. These effects are likely due to the short-wavelength–enriched light emitted by these devices. The results demonstrate that these devices have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio are 1.0 or higher, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the YDB spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the impact hypothesis for the YDB cooling. (Show more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We found that CTLA-4 deletion induced lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and organ-specific autoimmunity, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion affected both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. These findings have important implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, corresponding (Jurassic) diversification rate increases suggest that these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in the unique feeding habits of specialized herbivorous beetles. We propose that these genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. Our approach can also be applied to other protein molecules, such as enzymes and receptors, to improve their function and performance. This could have broad implications for biotechnology and medicine.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Our results indicate that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and the origins of technology. (Show more)

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with ∼twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with ∼12-fold decreased risk. APOE is also highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system that participates in normal synapse pruning and turnover. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in AD hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 1,200 km, which is the densest part of the Earth. The formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. One of the most important questions is how the inner core formed. In this paper, we propose a two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is a metastable phase. The second step is the nucleation of the hcp phase of iron, which is the stable phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective for understanding the formation of the Earth. They also provide a new perspective for understanding the origin of other dense cores in the solar system. Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are unknown, the drug’s effects on the brain’s reward system are well established. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. Reduced reactivity to methylphenidate is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors associated with marijuana use.

The human brain is a massively parallel computer that solves complex problems by processing streams of sensory data in parallel and generating parallel streams of hypotheses about the meaning of the world. The “transformer” models that have revolutionized artificial intelligence are also well suited to understanding how this computation might shape the brain’s response to the environment. Here, we show that these models robustly predict neural and behavioral responses to sentences across datasets and languages, and that model architecture contributes to predictive brain activity. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing shapes the brain’s response to the environment.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in many fields, including computer vision, speech recognition, and natural language processing. However, it is still in its infancy in scientific computing, where it is used to solve inverse problems in physics and chemistry. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This paradox is resolved by establishing a classification theory of conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the use of DL in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act in time, the spread of misinformation, and the inability of people to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that has been cited as evidence for this inability. The experiment’s critical design flaws were overlooked at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of the phenomenon. The paper discusses the flaws and the implications for the field of research.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. The uncultured human pathogen M. lepromatosis is associated with diffuse lepromatous leprosy and a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which reveals that it has retained the ability to infect the peripheral nervous system. Phylogenetic analyses suggest that M. lepromatosis and M. leprae are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. These findings have implications for the development of new leprosy vaccines. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also intimately related, as the latter is the statistical ensemble that captures the former. However, the study of the evolution of entanglement in isolated systems is a notoriously difficult task. It was possible so far only for noninteracting systems, whereas it was deemed unfeasible for interacting ones. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is the natural regime for the study of entanglement. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, which is integrable and therefore amenable to a complete analytical treatment. Our work opens the door to the study of entanglement in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. The only currently available vaccine is based on the inactivated virus, which is not suitable for mass vaccination. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, which is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate is highly attenuated, and the viral load in the lungs is reduced by more than 100-fold compared to the wild-type virus. In addition, the vaccine candidate induces high levels of neutralizing antibodies and protection against challenge with the wild-type virus. This vaccine candidate has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown, but it is thought to have been spread by rats. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work also provides a framework for studying the historical spread of plague in Europe. Future work should focus on the development of models for rodent transmission. This will allow us to understand the interplay between human and rodent vectors and the role of human behavior in the spread of plague.

The evolution of brain size is a key factor in understanding the rise of complex cognition. However, the evolution of brain size is biased by the fact that it is measured in terms of mass, which is not a good proxy for the number of neurons. This study uses the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of brain size in amniotes, from fish to humans. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study suggests that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family is a key regulator of actin filament disassembly. It is a key component of the actin depolymerization complex, which is the main regulator of actin filament disassembly. We show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context. We find that the mechanical state of the filament, such as local curvature and twist, can enhance or inhibit severing. We propose a mechanochemical model that explains our observations. This model suggests that ADF/cofilin can sever highly connected actin filament networks in cells, which is critical for many cellular processes. Our work provides a mechanistic understanding of how ADF/cofilin can regulate actin filament dynamics in a mechanical context. It also provides a framework for understanding how other proteins can regulate the mechanical state of actin filaments. This work is important for understanding the role of actin filaments in cells. It also provides a framework for understanding how other proteins can regulate the mechanical state of actin filaments.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry from Africa and an Austronesian ancestry from Southeast Asia. The genetic diversity is also influenced by geography, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity across Madagascar, which is essential to understand the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. It also provides a reference for future studies on the human history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This is a surprising result, because it suggests that people do not need to interact in person to be influenced by others’ emotions. This work also suggests that people’s positive emotions are not just a matter of personal disposition, but can be influenced by the positive emotions of others.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been shown to impact mRNA structure and function. In this study, we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications in coding regions, pseudouridine (Ψ), can modestly alter the rate of protein synthesis in a reconstituted translation system and human cells. We also provide evidence that the presence of Ψ can alter the rate of protein synthesis in a reconstituted translation system and human cells. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This study provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that higher worthwhile ratings are associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger personal relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone or watching television. Longitudinally, worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes independently of baseline levels. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We use a quantitative approach to test the hypothesis that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals. This result is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. Rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. However, the mechanism underlying this temperature-dependent growth is not known. Here, we show that mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at 37 °C than at 33 °C, and that this temperature-dependent growth is dependent on the MAVS protein and type I IFN induction. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus and may help to explain why rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity. This may have important implications for the development of antiviral strategies for the treatment of the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria sense their environment using a variety of sensory systems. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This process is mediated by the Chp chemosensory system, which regulates the production of cAMP and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. The methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein-like chemosensor PilJ directly interacts with the major pilin subunit PilA. Our results thus support a mechanochemical model where a chemosensory system measures the mechanically induced conformational changes in stretched type IV pili. This finding demonstrates that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanism may be important for the successful colonization of the human body by P. aeruginosa. Understanding how this bacterium senses its environment may lead to the development of new strategies for controlling this pathogen. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the consequences of this development for the quality of surface waters are not well understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the biological integrity of water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides in agriculture should be reduced and that the existing environmental regulations should be enforced more strictly.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology of SARS-CoV-2. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa. We also provide evidence that deer are a reservoir for SARS-CoV-2, and that the virus can be transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. A more comprehensive understanding of the ecology of SARS-CoV-2 is needed to develop effective strategies for its control. Our study provides a model for a more proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world for decades. The proliferation of large dams in the Mekong River Basin, the Amazon River Basin, and the Congo River Basin is a global concern. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by chronic inflammation. However, the origin of this response is still debated. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric amyloid-β (Aβ) secreted by neurons is the primary source of inflammatory factors in AD. We demonstrate that Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors in AD. Moreover, we show that the human brain is also enriched in Aβ-burdened neurons, suggesting that this process may be more widespread than previously thought. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary source of inflammation in AD, and that this process may be more widespread than previously thought. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method to study the folding of a large protein in high structural detail. The method is based on the observation that the folding of a protein is accompanied by a change in the rate of exchange of hydrogen atoms with deuterium. We have used this method to study the folding of the maltose binding protein. The results indicate that the folding of the protein is accompanied by the formation of a distinct intermediate that is an obligatory step in the folding process. The intermediate is composed of segments that are distant in the sequence but adjacent in the native protein. The intermediate is also composed of segments that are most protected in the early collapse of the protein into a compact state. The intermediate is the site of three destabilizing mutations that slow the folding of the protein. The results suggest that the intermediate is a common step in the folding of many proteins. This is an important step in the understanding of the process of protein folding. (Show more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress and are known to function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap of Np4-capped RNAs in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 accumulation. We also show that the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the cap of noncapped RNAs, is the predominant decapping enzyme in E. coli cells experiencing disulfide stress. This enzyme prefers to remove capped RNAs over their noncapped counterparts, and it does so by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to remove other 5′ termini. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of the disease. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore immune function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This information is essential for the development of sustainable practices and the mitigation of the negative effects of human activities on the planet.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system can be in a critical state and yet continue to change spontaneously. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of the timescales involved, and the system can change on all of these timescales. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm, and we identify female-derived proteins that support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the viral component of the microbiome, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which is the first of its kind. We find that the human virome is associated with a variety of diseases, including cancer, diabetes, and autism. This study provides a resource for future studies of the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties. The HSRL is capable of measuring aerosol and cloud properties with high-resolution and high-spectral resolution. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate the ACI process. The observations show that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI processes. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature history of Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The isotopic record of the paleotemperatures of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a method for determining the paleotemperature of ancient surface environments based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth's surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion conduits in the cell and are regulated by two types of gates, one for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other for slow inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide insights into the BK channel’s unique properties and may help to understand the physiological roles of the BK channel. They also provide a theoretical basis for the development of BK channel modulators. (Show more)

The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC) and initiate infection. Here, we show that the malaria parasite exploits the physical properties of the RBC to facilitate invasion. We use a combination of real-time deformability cytometry and flicker spectroscopy to show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the RBC, increasing the cytoskeletal tension and reducing the bending modulus of the cell membrane. These changes in the RBC are directly correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite is exploiting the physical properties of the RBC to facilitate invasion. This would represent a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces. This finding has implications for the development of new antimalarial strategies. (Show more)

Diamond is a promising material for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly without phonon instability by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized by applying tensile strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The machine-learning approach used in this work can be applied to other materials to predict the stability of their structures under strain. This approach can also be extended to other materials and applications, such as energy storage and conversion.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. These findings may help to develop strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus infection in the temperate regions. Our study also provides a model system

The brain is thought to build a hierarchical representation of the structure of a sentence, from the simplest to the most complex syntactic units. However, there is no direct evidence that the brain performs this operation. Here, we used intracranial recordings to show that the brain builds a hierarchy of syntactic units during the processing of a sentence. The results suggest that the brain performs a merge operation, which applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. This merge operation is consistent with a neural implementation of a left-corner parser, which is thought to be the most efficient way of parsing a sentence. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be important for understanding the brain’s efficient processing of language. (Show more)

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and tissue homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the Wnt signal. We hypothesize that differential regulation of redundant genes may be a general feature of the evolution of animal development.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that this effect is mediated by dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA), which in turn inhibit the LH. However, we also found that this circuit is not necessary for the induction of eating. Instead, we found that stimulation-induced eating is mediated by a circuit in the LH that projects to the caudal part of the ventral tegmental area and the locus coeruleus. This circuit is necessary for the induction of eating. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit is not involved in the hunger or satiety mechanisms that govern normal feeding.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen in agricultural systems is a major driver of the global food supply. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and their nitrogen-fixing bacteria would allow for the delivery of nitrogen in agriculture in a sustainable manner. Here, we have developed a system in which the nitrogen-fixing bacterium can only fix nitrogen when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. This synthetic system could be used to deliver nitrogen in agriculture in a sustainable manner. (Show more)

The Peruvian Amazon is the most deforested region in the world, and the Peruvian government has committed to halting deforestation by 2030. To achieve this goal, the government has invested in remote-sensed deforestation alerts and in community-based monitoring. However, the effectiveness of these programs is unknown. We study a community-based monitoring program that was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities in the Peruvian Amazon. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities, but the estimated effects are imprecise. The results imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but all are part of the animal’s body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body by outsourcing its hearing to its web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of its own web threads, which is used to localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave. The spider can supersize its web to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of hearing in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study also provides a unique model for studying the evolution of hearing organs and the relationship between hearing and body size. (Show more)

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and aerosols are difficult to disentangle. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health benefits of reducing fossil-fuel-related emissions and aerosols. We find that removing fossil-fuel-related emissions and aerosols can save 3.61 million lives per year and reduce global temperature by 0.51 °C. The health benefits are even greater if we additionally control nonfossil anthropogenic sources. The model results indicate that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. The model results also suggest that the health benefits are greater if we additionally reduce tropospheric ozone and methane. This study highlights the importance of reducing fossil-fuel-related emissions and aerosols to save lives and mitigate climate change. The model results provide a quantitative assessment of the health and climate impacts of air pollution and aerosols. The model can be used to inform policy decisions. The neuroblastoma-associated kinase ALK is a protooncogene that is mutated in anaplastic large cell lymphoma and in a subset of neuroblastoma. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALK/Ltk are activated by zebrafish ALKALs. Zebrafish ALKALs are expressed in the neural crest and cause ectopic iridophore development. We further show that zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of the neural crest-derived iridophores. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of ALK/Ltk family receptors in neural crest development. This is of importance for the understanding of the role of ALK/Ltk in human cancer and neuroblastoma. Furthermore, our results suggest that ALKALs are potential therapeutic targets in neuroblastoma.

The emergence of Yersinia pestis as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in human history. The pathogen has caused devastating outbreaks throughout human history, and ancient DNA evidence has shown it afflicted human populations as far back as the Neolithic. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. We find that the Bronze Age population carrying Y. pestis was not a distinct lineage, but rather a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of Y. pestis. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

The fate of carbon (C) in agricultural systems is a key determinant of global climate change. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has led to massive C losses to the atmosphere. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems on Mollisols to mitigate these losses remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that incorporate legumes and manure into annual cropping systems can increase soil C storage and the use of soil C by soil microbes. These practices can therefore play a key role in climate-smart agriculture. Our results highlight the importance of integrating livestock and legumes into annual cropping systems to mitigate climate change. This approach can help to restore the ecological services of grasslands and provide a sustainable source of food and income for farmers.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for spillover and developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, to estimate the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinators. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are either necessary or sufficient for pigment production, including a carbonic anhydrase that increases nectar pH, an aryl-alcohol oxidase that produces a pigment precursor, and a ferritin-like catalase that protects the pigment from degradation by hydrogen peroxide. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular framework for understanding the evolution of this trait.

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a unique population from southern Germany dating to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our data indicate that while men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results provide insights into the complex demographic processes that may have contributed to shape the modern European genetic landscape. (Show more)

The emergence of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) in humans has caused ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens is a global health concern. However, the pathogen landscape and surveillance of emerging pathogens in resource-scarce settings is limited. We used metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate a large periurban hospital in Cambodia, where undifferentiated febrile illness is common. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. We identified chikungunya virus as an early indicator of a national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. Pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce settings is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. The human genome is replicated by the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) holoenzyme, which is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA synthesis in humans. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it has been possible to evolve ribozymes that can catalyze the replication of RNA, but it has not been possible to evolve a ribozyme that can replicate RNA in a PCR-like fashion. Here, we report the successful evolution of a ribozyme that can replicate RNA in a PCR-like fashion. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life in the laboratory. It also provides a powerful tool for the study of RNA replication and the origin of life. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical changes in cities over time and to study the spatial dynamics of urban change. Our results also provide a new way to measure the success of urban policy.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can reduce mortality and improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. The results provide a reference for the clinical treatment of COVID-19.

The role of metal micronutrients in fungal growth and metabolism is well established, but the existence of fungal natural products that bind and regulate metal homeostasis is less well known. Here we report the existence of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster was identified in Aspergillus fumigatus, and the cluster was shown to bind copper and impact intracellular copper pools. Xanthocillin-treated fungi were shown to be inhibited by copper, and the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster was shown to be present in other filamentous fungi. The existence of fungal natural products that bind and regulate metal homeostasis suggests that the study of these compounds may provide insight into the evolution of metal homeostasis in fungi and the role of these compounds in fungal interactions with competing microbes. This study also suggests that the study of metal homeostasis in fungi may provide insight into the evolution of fungal metabolism and the role of these compounds in fungal interactions with competing microbes. Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is unclear what role these cells play in the pathogenesis of the disease. Here we show that Th17 cells can directly transition to Th1-like cells and that this subset is critical for the development of colitis. Th17 cells can also provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis.
