Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes and different clinical manifestations. The disease is also progressive, with motor neuron degeneration occurring long before the onset of paralysis. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and develop therapeutics. This method will enable the study of disease mechanisms and development of therapeutics in ALS. It will also enable the study of the effects of disease-causing mutations in ALS patients, which is currently not possible. This will lead to a better understanding of the disease and the development of more effective therapies. This will be of benefit to ALS patients worldwide. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens, including Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the causative agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis. We now demonstrate that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates Anaplasma colonization. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to facilitate transmission to vertebrate hosts. This knowledge will be useful for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of life. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is obscured by the limited known diversity of early branching members of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”). Here, we describe a basal member of Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. This study also provides important information for understanding the evolution of the avian body plan and the origin of the modern avian bauplan. (Show more)

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand its behavior. One way to do this is to understand the role of individual components of the system. Here we show that stratospheric water vapor plays an important role in the climate system. We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere increases with the temperature of the troposphere, implying the existence of a feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. This work shows that we need to understand the climate system in its entirety to understand its behavior. (Show more)

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. The color of a vertebrate can be influenced by its environment, and the color change can be used for communication. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein is present in the skin of anurans and binds biliverdin, the pigment that is responsible for the color of vertebrate blood. This is the first example of a serpin family protein that binds biliverdin in vertebrates. Our results provide evidence of the evolution of a new mechanism of color change in vertebrates. Additionally, we show that this protein has a physiological function in the color change of anurans. This study contributes to our understanding of the evolution of color in vertebrates. (Show more)

We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase, which demethylated NANOG mRNA at an m6A residue in the 3′-UTR. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were made from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method using standard conservation treatments to identify the animal origin of parchment. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds in the Meishan section, China. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle precedes the extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. The precise age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. The age model will also be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the presence of the D614G mutation and the wild-type protein. We find that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent conformational changes required for membrane fusion. These results provide insight into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure of the spike protein and may inform the design of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are central to chemistry and are the basis of the periodic table. The chemical hardness and electronegativity of an atom are two central chemical properties. They are the second- and first-order chemical potentials, respectively, and are the chemical potential of the electron in a given atom relative to the vacuum and the negative of the chemical potential of the electron in a given atom relative to the homogeneous electron gas. We calculate these two properties as a function of pressure and find that they decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we show that the pseudo–noble-gas elements Ni, Pd, and Pt are electron acceptors, while the electron donors are the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) and the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd). Our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales are useful tools for understanding and predicting the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure. They are also useful for predicting the chemical behavior of compounds under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. However, the net effect is uncertain because of the complex interactions between climate, fire, and carbon cycle. We show that human demography, through fire suppression, can reduce fire activity and mitigate warming. This effect is most effective under lower emission scenarios. Our results suggest that climate–fire feedbacks may be used to mitigate global warming, but that the benefits will be limited if emissions continue to rise.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. We also show that the catabolism of this glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This study provides a new example of how animals can regulate the activities of their associated microbes, and it suggests that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a more common mechanism than previously thought. This study also provides a model for understanding the regulation of the activities of symbiotic microbes in other animal hosts. (Show more)

The study of topics in text data is a key problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a generative model to infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. Motivated by known patterns in suicide and homicide by gender and recent research on gender biases in semantic space, we identify the gender bias of our topics (e.g., a topic about pain medication is feminine). We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the mid-14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium into Europe, after which it established itself in rodents. We show that this assumption is not supported by our analysis of climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from rodent reservoirs in Asia. We find that the introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe was a recurrent event, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y between the introduction of the bacterium and the onset of the plague epidemic. This result suggests that the plague bacterium was introduced into Europe repeatedly, and that the establishment of the disease in Europe was not a single event, but rather a process that took place over several decades. This result has important implications for our understanding of the history of the plague pandemic.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that has been described as a mass mortality event. The disease is characterized by behavioral changes, lesions, loss of turgor, limb autotomy, and death. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by starfish. The virus is also present in the environment and in the tissues of nonaffected starfish. This suggests that the virus is spread by the starfish. The starfish is therefore a major agent of the disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of novel targets for therapy is of great importance. Here we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We further show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling in addition to targeting IL1RAP is effective in suppressing the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The identification of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based therapy of AML is of great importance for the treatment of this disease. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique case study for understanding the settlement history of Madagascar. (Show more)

While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. Our approach can also be applied to other protein molecules, such as enzymes and receptors, to improve their function and performance. This could have broad implications for biotechnology and medicine.

Crop expert surveys are a key source of information on crop status, but are often underutilized in agricultural monitoring. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that the resulting Crop Condition Index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be applied to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the impact of climate change on crop production.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This model provides a neurobiological substrate for the binding of linguistic features within the brain. It also suggests a mechanism for the formation of short-term memory in the brain.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The molecular evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of the photosynthetic apparatus and the origin of the eukaryotic cell. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is still poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome, which is accompanied by bursts of gene losses. Our findings suggest that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner. This evolutionary process may have been crucial for the origin of the eukaryotic cell. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of South Africa to extreme droughts. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in South Africa to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for informing the development of drought risk management strategies. The high-resolution ensemble approach used here can be applied to other regions of the world to assess the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to drought risk. This will be critical for informing the development of drought risk management strategies.

The first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, released more energy in 2 minutes than the sun does in 1 million years. The explosion created a blast wave that shattered glass and melted copper transmission lines. The blast also created a shock wave that compressed sand into a glassy material known as trinitite. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, in a sample of red trinitite. The discovery of this material, which is the oldest anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, demonstrates that transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions are suitable for the synthesis of quasicrystals and for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems. The discovery of this material also demonstrates that the first nuclear explosion was not the first nuclear explosion. (Show more)

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster proteins, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. These results indicate that Ycf54 is a cyclase subunit in oxygenic phototrophs, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes, to assess the roles of ASK1 during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We found that ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes ameliorated EAE severity, whereas ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. We also found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages induces a proinflammatory environment, which subsequently activates astrocytes to exacerbate neuroinflammation. Microglia-specific ASK1 deletion was achieved using a CX3CR1CreER system, and we found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest and warmest on record. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of drought years is strongly influenced by the occurrence of warm conditions. We also find that the probability of drought years is increased by human activities. These findings suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions that have created acute human and ecosystem impacts in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests a potential target for the treatment of autism. This study also provides a model system for the study of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This study will be useful for the development of a mechanistic understanding of the etiology of autism

The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and loss-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of ORAI1, which result in hematological abnormalities and myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The Stormorken syndrome is a rare disease with a high mortality rate in the first year of life. The identification of the molecular basis of the disease and the development of therapies based on the knowledge gained in this study may improve the quality of life of patients with Stormorken syndrome. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of the cell membrane, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may help to identify new therapeutic targets. (Show more)

The role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses is increasingly recognized, but the mechanisms underlying virus spillover from bats remain unclear. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibits the function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibits proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses and the potential of MTX as a therapeutic target for the prevention of viral spillover from bats.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus cancer cells must meet the increased demand for energy and biosynthetic precursors. One-carbon units are critical for these processes, and thus cancer cells have evolved to increase the rate of one-carbon unit production. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of one-carbon unit production, and thus a promising target for cancer therapy. Here we identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and that formate-dependent SHMT inhibition is uniquely effective in B-cell lines. Thus, formate is a promising target for the treatment of B-cell lymphomas. Collectively, these studies provide a foundation for the development of small-molecule SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapy. This is the first study to show that formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and that formate-dependent SHMT inhibition is uniquely effective in B-cell lymphomas. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we observe that the inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS is a general feature of the disease. This finding may provide a unifying mechanism for the development of ALS, and may also have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used in a variety of applications, including atom interferometry, atom-based quantum information processing, and quantum simulation. The photonic crystals can be used to control the interactions between atoms, which can be used to study many-body physics and quantum simulation. The photonic crystals can be used to control the emission of light from atoms, which can be used to study light-matter interactions and quantum optics.

The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 thousand years ago) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is dated to ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

The acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y is estimated to be 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This acceleration is consistent with the climate-change–driven rate of sea level rise over the same period, and the quadratic extrapolation of the quadratic implies global mean sea level could rise 65 ± 12 cm by 2100 compared with 2005. This estimate is consistent with the IPCC AR5 model projections.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a more general erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate is a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure and dynamics of this intermediate, providing atomic-resolution characterization of stable intermediates in enzyme active sites. This integrated approach is able to identify the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains as well as the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site. The detailed picture of structure and reactivity that emerges from this work highlights the fate of the L-serine hydroxyl leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into the structure and dynamics of enzyme active sites. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment available, and the disease has a high case fatality rate. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a recently developed antiviral, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir treatment initiated 24 h prior to inoculation completely prevented MERS-CoV−induced clinical disease, strongly inhibited MERS-CoV replication in respiratory tissues, and prevented the formation of lung lesions. Therapeutic remdesivir treatment initiated 12 h postinoculation also provided a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, as the emergence of new coronaviruses is a major public health concern. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel cycle that is synchronized with the host’s circadian clock. We propose that this strategy may be used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This study also highlights the importance of the host’s immune system in the regulation of the symbiosis. (Show more)

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, with disproportionate effects on students of color and students with disabilities. This study tests whether teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. In two experiments, teachers who were trained to adopt an empathic mindset about discipline reduced their use of suspension and increased students’ respect for them. In a randomized field experiment, this intervention halved suspension rates in schools where it was implemented. These findings suggest that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV S proteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved MERS viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved MERS viruses used endosomal fusion-activating proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a major impact on these emissions. Increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering outlets is a simple and effective way to reduce the environmental impact of the food system. This study shows that doubling the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering outlet increases the proportion of diners choosing vegetarian meals by 40%. This is equivalent to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61%. This study also shows that the impact of increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals is concentrated among diners who are less likely to choose vegetarian meals. This suggests that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could be a cost-effective way to increase the proportion of plant-based meals consumed by the population. This approach could be used to achieve the goals of the UK government’s 2025 target to increase the proportion of plant-based meals to 20% of all meals purchased and the 2030 target to increase the proportion of plant-based meals to 25%.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The data also suggest that the cell surface proteome is a dynamic target for cancer therapy. This work is a step toward a systems-level understanding of the cancer cell surfaceome. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has been characterized by a rapid spread and severe morbidity. The molecular basis for this spread is largely unknown, but it is hypothesized that SARS-CoV-2 may be evading the host immune system. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is hypothesized to be involved in immune suppression. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and may inform the development of therapeutics and vaccines. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. It also provides a potential target for the treatment of cerebral edema. The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs (ETVECs). ETV2-mediated conversion of fibroblasts into ETVECs is accompanied by the induction of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1. ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the generation of ECs for therapeutic purposes. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. We show that zebrafish augmentor ligands play an important role in pigment development. Deficiency in augmentor ligands results in strong impairment in iridophore patterning of embryonic and adult zebrafish that is phenocopied in zebrafish deficient in Ltk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a model system for the study of ligand-activated RTKs in a vertebrate model system. This will be important for the study of the function of RTKs in development and cancer. Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder characterized by insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although STING is known to be involved in the regulation of immune response, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells and mice caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the transcription factor Pax6 was down-regulated and its nuclear localization was lost in STING-βKO β-cells. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings provide insights into the molecular basis of STING-related T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus using in vitro experiments. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also showed that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions. The atheroprone disturbed flow is a key environmental factor that promotes the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the underlying mechanisms are largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the atheroprone disturbed flow is critical for the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggests a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate government records of wildfires that had to be extinguished or managed by state or federal agencies from 1992 to 2012, and examined geographic and seasonal extents of human-ignited wildfires relative to lightning-ignited wildfires. Humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the coterminous United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. During the 21-y time period, the human-caused fire season was three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season and added an average of 40,000 wildfires per year across the United States. Human-started wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical changes in cities over time and to study the spatial dynamics of urban change. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods is a key determinant of neighborhood change. This work is important for understanding the physical dynamics of cities and for developing effective policies to improve the physical appearances of neighborhoods.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel (sTRP1) that mediates the avoidance behavior of scorpions toward Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. We further demonstrated that dTRPγ ion channel in Drosophila melanogaster is a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents, which mediates avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection are likely important. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques, and we assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can inform the design of clinical trials of antiviral drugs and the development of treatment guidelines. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the majority of the coral’s photosynthetic capacity. While the symptoms of bleaching have been extensively characterized, the underlying causes remain largely unknown. Here, we show that altered nutrient cycling is a primary driver of the functional breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This may have important implications for the conservation of coral reefs in a changing climate. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky and allows the dissemination of cancer cells to other organs. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor model Drosophila melanogaster-BMP-JNK-Mmp2-induced tumorigenesis leads to a dysbiotic microbiome and barrier dysfunction. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis, leading to a lifespan extension. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the interplay between intestinal tumors, the microbiome, and host lifespan. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but resistance to chemotherapy is common. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression was associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. Thus, cirmtuzumab may be a promising therapeutic agent for the treatment of breast cancer.

The timing of the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is controversial. We show that the start of the Bølling interstadial, the first of three successive glacial-state greenhouse gas concentrations and climate conditions, is synchronous with the start of massive volcanic eruptions from Mount Takahe, New Zealand. The eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which, in turn, caused a poleward shift of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and a rapid advance of the Southern Ocean ice sheet. This scenario explains the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation and the coincidence of the Bølling interstadial with the start of the Mount Takahe eruptions. The Mount Takahe eruptions are the only known volcanic eruptions to have caused a climate change. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can have a major impact on the climate system. The Mount Takahe eruptions are also the only known volcanic eruptions to have caused a climate change.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In mammals, however, the CNS is incapable of regenerating after injury, and the regeneration capacity of the PNS is limited. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the C. elegans nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling cascade. This DLK-independent regeneration is triggered by sensory activity and is reminiscent of a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings suggest that DLK-independent regeneration is a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between DLK-independent regeneration and lesion conditioning, a phenomenon producing robust regeneration in the mammalian CNS. Taken as a whole, our study unites disparate forms of regeneration to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. This work also suggests that DLK-independent regeneration is a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of all living organisms. In eukaryotes, recombination is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific DNA sequences. In this study, we use a population genomic approach to identify the locations of these binding sites in the genome of a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that the locations of these sites are highly conserved, suggesting that they may have been conserved throughout evolution. We also find that the binding sites are more likely to be found in the promoter regions of genes than in the coding regions. These results provide a detailed view of the locations of the positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–binding sites in a flowering plant. Taken together, these results provide a detailed view of the locations of the positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–binding sites in a flowering plant. The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of networks of brain regions that are functionally and anatomically connected and that are anatomically and functionally segregated. Here, we used metabolic imaging to identify and validate the dominant resting state network in healthy and disease populations. We also demonstrated that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network, and that this network is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. Finally, we showed that the dominant resting state network is functionally modulated by task performance, and that this modulation is reduced in Parkinson’s disease. These results provide a direct link between the temporal dynamics of the BOLD signal and the organization of the brain in health and disease. They also provide a framework for the functional analysis of the resting brain.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is a major determinant of mRNA stability and translation. The existence of 5′ cap-like structures on mRNA has been demonstrated in bacteria and archaea, but the existence of 5′ cap-like structures on mRNA in eukaryotes has been debated. We show that 5′ cap-like structures are found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. These 5′ cap-like structures are not found on cytoplasmic mRNAs. The 5′ cap-like structures are not required for translation, but they do affect mRNA stability. These results define an additional 5′ cap-like structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ cap-like structure could modulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This could be important for the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes. (Show more)

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control in people with type 1 and type 2 diabetes can prevent or delay the development of microvascular complications. However, the long-term effects of intensive glucose control on the development of macrovascular complications are less clear. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood DNA persist for several years during the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study, a long-term follow-up study of people with type 1 and type 2 diabetes who participated in the DCCT. These epigenetic differences are associated with glycemia in the DCCT and EDIC Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for the metabolic memory effect of the DCCT. They also suggest that epigenetic alterations in blood DNA may be a useful biomarker for the long-term effects of glucose control. Future studies are needed to confirm these findings and to explore the clinical utility of epigenetic biomarkers. (Show more)

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The etiology of this disorder is complex and involves multiple factors. In the last few years, the existence of a bidirectional communication between the brain and the gut has been suggested. This study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and may be a previously unidentified target in the management of this disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, which are responsible for the characteristic aroma. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is largely unknown, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit flavor is not understood. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase, which catalyzes the biosynthesis of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. It also opens the door to the development of tomato varieties with improved flavor. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the field. Here we use high-throughput experiments to show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper as temperatures deviate from ambient conditions, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes: (i) more diverse communities are more likely to contain species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity under thermal stress, and (ii) the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect increases at high and low temperatures, indicating that species interactions play a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of global warming and biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to reflect different aspects of local space. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be responsible for the formation of a grid of local space, are anatomically distinct from other cell types and that they are strongly coupled among themselves. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC cell types in vivo and will be useful for understanding the function of MEC in navigation. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of the host and the parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also shows that the FT gene in dodder does not function in flowering induction. This may be due to the fact that the FT gene in dodder is not expressed in the leaves, where FT is synthesized in the host. This may be a general feature of parasitic plants.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by loss of dopaminergic neurons and by the presence of Lewy bodies, which contain aggregates of misfolded proteins. The mechanisms by which these processes occur are not known. Here we show that the dopamine-producing cells are connected to other brain regions by a system of fibers that extend from the dopamine-producing cells to other brain regions. We also show that the dopamine-producing cells are connected to other brain regions by a system of specialized integrative units. These results suggest that the dopamine-producing cells are part of a system that is critical to the control of mood and motivation and that is affected in Parkinson’s disease. Understanding the nature of this system could lead to new approaches to the treatment of the disease. (Show more)

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate and are therefore critical for maintaining normal heart function. However, SANCs are unable to maintain normal heart rate in the absence of external stimuli. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN function. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SANCs, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si may promote insect resistance by priming JA-mediated defense responses. These findings provide insights into the underlying mechanisms of the beneficial effects of Si on plant resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an important enzyme in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the function of macrophages in innate immunity. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage function.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic compounds or to seek out nutrients. Thus, plants must rely on their senses to detect and respond to environmental cues. In this work, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver siRNAs to plants, where they can silence a gene of interest. We also show that the size, shape, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. This work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biology.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient loading to lakes comes from nonpoint sources, such as agricultural fields and urban areas. However, the role of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication has been largely overlooked. We show that small tributaries deliver a disproportionately large amount of nutrients to the world’s fifth largest lake, Lake Michigan. These findings suggest that nutrient management efforts targeting small tributaries could have a large impact on the health of coastal ecosystems. Our results highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication and provide a blueprint for future research and management.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems theory. We also find that the network dynamics can be accelerated by the presence of a small number of “catalyst” reactions that are able to access the rare combinations of chemical concentrations that are required to maintain the steady state. This result suggests that the presence of catalysts may be a general feature of complex systems that are exposed to rare environmental forcing.

NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) are a class of autoantibodies that cause autoimmune encephalitis. Although NMDAR-Abs are believed to disrupt receptor function, how blocking this excitatory synaptic receptor can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities—or even seizures—is poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change intrinsic cortical connections and neuronal population dynamics to alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that NMDAR-Abs may be a useful model for studying the mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in other autoimmune encephalitis. This may lead to the development of new therapies for these patients.
